Nichols Is Found Guilty in Oklahoma Bombing
 By MONICA DAVEY
 
 Published: May 27, 2004
 
 http://www.nytimes.com/2004/05/27/national/27nichols.html?th
 
 
 cALESTER, Okla., May 26 - Nine years after a homemade bomb ripped through the federal building in Oklahoma City, Terry L. Nichols was convicted on Wednesday of 161 counts of first-degree murder in the blast, and a state jury has to decide whether he should be executed. 
 
 Mr. Nichols, 49, was already serving a life term for federal charges of conspiracy and involuntary manslaughter in connection to the bombing. Yet his level of involvement in the explosion that killed 168 people has long been a matter of debate.
 
 At his federal trial in Denver seven years ago, the jurors rejected the most serious charges of premeditated murder against him. But the swift verdict here placed Mr. Nichols firmly at the heart of the plot, beside Timothy J. McVeigh, an old Army friend of Mr. Nichols who was executed in 2001.
 
 I think Mr. Nichols should follow in his friend's footsteps, right into the dirt nap room.

Let's see, nine years ago...that would make him 40 years old. That's about the age I lost the last of my young man's idealism for good. Timothy McVeigh was younger still, I believe. These two guys never had an original thought I bet. They sat around the kitchen tables of older, "wiser" men and absorbed the hate-filled rhetoric they heard. They mistakenly thought they were acting in the purest morality, bravely putting to action what others only would rant about. 
 
 I was in Oklahoma the day McVeigh died. The state stopped and listened to the live radio feed from Terre Haute, IN, describing in great detail his expressions and demeanor, and finally his face in death. I really don't know what most Sooners thought about it, but I wished he could have become an old man, pressing his face against the bars on a nice spring day, or watching the events of 9/11 unfold, and with each passing year reflecting on the stupidity of his youth.
 
 I wish the same for Nichols, and in his old age, he tells authorities the full story so that all the others who were involved can be brought to justice.
